title: Bold in Jerusalem
objective: See how the early church proclaims Christ with courage amid miracles, threats, and prayerful dependence.

required_passages.text: Peter said, 'In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk!' ... all the people ran together... Peter preached Jesus' resurrection... 'there is salvation in no one else' ... the council commanded them not to speak... Peter and John answered, 'We cannot but speak of what we have seen and heard.' ... they prayed... 'grant to your servants to continue to speak your word with all boldness' ... they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and continued to speak the word of God with boldness.

segments.audio_script: A healed beggar opens the door for bold gospel witness. Today we see miracle, message, persecution, and united prayer.

Listen to Acts 3 and 4. At the temple gate called Beautiful, Peter said to a lame man, 'In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk.' Immediately he was healed and praised God. Peter preached that this happened by faith in Jesus, whom God raised from the dead. The priests and Sadducees arrested Peter and John, yet many believed. Before the council, Peter declared, 'There is salvation in no one else.' The leaders threatened them not to speak in Jesus' name. Peter and John replied, 'We cannot but speak of what we have seen and heard.' The church prayed for boldness, and the place was shaken. They were filled with the Holy Spirit and spoke God's word boldly, sharing possessions so none were in need.

The apostles minister in Jerusalem's temple context where the same authorities who condemned Jesus now oppose His followers. Healing authenticates proclamation, but the core issue is Jesus' exclusive lordship.

Miracles in Acts are signs pointing to Christ, not ends in themselves. Opposition does not silence the church; it drives prayer. The church asks not for safety but boldness. Spirit filling repeatedly empowers mission. Shared generosity shows the gospel's social fruit.
Key themes include Jesus' name and power, resurrection witness, exclusive salvation in Christ, courage under threat, prayer for boldness, Spirit empowerment, and sacrificial community.
Reflect on this: Do you seek comfort or boldness? How can your church's prayer life and generosity better display the gospel?
The church proclaims Jesus despite pressure. Next, we see internal purity and the first martyr as mission expands.
